answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
1. **Frame 1**: At the right‐hand corner is a STOP sign, beneath which appears to be a “No Left Turn” sign (a left‐pointing arrow with a diagonal slash). A “ONE WAY” sign with an arrow pointing right also seems to be posted. Directly ahead is a guardrail and a fenced‐off/gated driveway—so proceeding straight does not appear viable.  
2. **Frame 2**: The same signs (STOP plus “No Left Turn” and “ONE WAY” right arrow) remain clearly visible. The fenced area ahead confirms that going straight is blocked.  
3. **Frame 3**: From this angle, the “No Left Turn” sign under the STOP sign is even more apparent; the arrow under the universal “no” slash is pointing left. Straight ahead is a private or closed driveway, re‐emphasizing that one cannot go forward.  
4. **Frame 4**: We see more of the guardrail and the gated area ahead, ruling out going straight. The signage requiring a stop and prohibiting a left turn still stands out on the right post.  
5. **Frame 5**: The final frame again shows the closed driveway straight ahead and the guardrail on the left side, reinforcing that the only open and lawful option is the right turn (as indicated by the “ONE WAY →” sign).  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
• The stop sign requires the driver to come to a complete stop.  
• The “No Left Turn” sign prohibits turning left.  
• The roadway straight ahead is fenced off / gated and is not an option.  
• A “One Way →” sign suggests that to the right is the valid (and likely only) way to proceed.  

**Match to Answer Choices**  
A. Turn left – Not allowed; the “No Left Turn” sign prohibits this.  
B. Go straight – Not possible; the way ahead is blocked by a closed gate.  
C. Turn right – This is the only legal and open direction, as indicated by the “One Way” sign.  

<answer>C</answer>
